title: Why are airplanes slower than they used to be? - Alex Gendler

title: The counterintuitive way to be more persuasive - Niro Sivanathan

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to undervalue a product due to its price

options.text: Participants rated Tim as having a significantly higher GPA than Tom

options.label: C

options.text: Participants were unable to evaluate their cognitive aptitude

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because strong arguments will be more persuasive than weak arguments

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because the listener will only remember the strong arguments

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of considering multiple perspectives when making a decision

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: What it takes to be racially literate - Priya Vulchi and Winona Guo

multiple-choice.question: What was the speakers' initial understanding of racism four years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: They thought they had a deep understanding of racism.

options.label: B
options.text: They thought they had a superficial understanding of racism.

options.label: C
options.text: They thought they didn't understand racism at all.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speakers decide to do to gain a better understanding of racism?

options.label: B
options.text: They talked to random people and collected personal stories about race.

options.label: D
options.text: They joined a club about racism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "heart gap" in racial literacy, according to the speakers?

options.label: A
options.text: An inability to understand the larger, systemic ways in which racism operates.

options.label: B
options.text: An inability to understand each of our experiences and be compassionate beyond lip service.

options.label: C
options.text: An inability to understand statistics about racism.

options.label: D
options.text: An inability to understand the history of racism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "mind gap" in racial literacy, according to the speakers?

options.label: A
options.text: An inability to understand each of our experiences and be compassionate beyond lip service.

options.label: B
options.text: An inability to understand the larger, systemic ways in which racism operates.

options.label: C
options.text: An inability to understand statistics about racism.

options.label: D
options.text: An inability to understand the history of racism.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the speakers think that throwing out just statistics about racism can be problematic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can lead to a complete understanding of racism.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can lead to a dangerously incomplete understanding of racism.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can lead to a lack of knowledge about racism.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can lead to a lack of compassion about racism.

multiple-choice.question: What do the speakers think is necessary to truly grasp the situation of someone like Ronnie, who has a family member who is wrongly incarcerated?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding the statistics about incarceration rates.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the systemic ways in which racism operates.

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding the personal experience of Ronnie.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the speakers think that understanding the historical context behind someone's reaction is important?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can lead to unnecessary fighting.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can lead to a deeper understanding of the person's reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can lead to a lack of compassion.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it can lead to a lack of knowledge.

multiple-choice.question: What do the speakers think is necessary to create a shared American culture that identifies and embraces the different values and norms within diverse communities?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignoring the heart gap and focusing on the mind gap.

options.label: B
options.text: Ignoring the mind gap and focusing on the heart gap.

options.label: C
options.text: Co-creating a culture that bridges the gap between hearts and minds.

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on individual experiences and ignoring the systemic ways in which racism operates.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the speakers' book, "The Classroom Index"?

options.label: A
options.text: To share personal stories about racism.

options.label: C
options.text: To bridge the gap between hearts and minds by pairing personal stories with research.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the systemic ways in which racism operates.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the speakers think that racial literacy is important?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it can lead to a deeper understanding of individual experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can lead to a deeper understanding of the systemic ways in which racism operates.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can lead to a more compassionate and equitable society.

options.label: C
